ext_description.p: A AlternatePartRelationship is a type of where the relating part represents the base part and the related part represents the alternate part.

It specifies that any version of the alternate part, may be used in place of any version of the base part, regardless of its usages and of its versions. The relationship established by the AlternatePartRelationship is not symmetric: if part B is an alternate part for part A, part A is not implied to be an alternate part for part B.
ext_description.note: If a part is an alternate for another part, it is understood that there is no interest in keeping track of which part, the base or any alternates specified, is used as a particular instance of the base part within a part structure

An organization may track design changes for a base part, and establish effectivity conditions for the use of that base part in various assemblies to be manufactured. The use of an alternate part implies that an organization does not specify any particular version of the alternate part nor establish effectivities relating to it
An AlternatePartRelationship may relate parts of any kind, provided both related objects identify parts of the same part category.
An AlternatePartRelationship for which the base part is an assembly involves that the entire part structure of the alternate part may be used in place of the base part and its part structure.

This concept usually refers to form, fit, function, and quality. Additional properties such as performance, noise, endurance, or reliability may also be considered as a prerequisite for the replacement
ext_description.example: Two bolts of the same size are parts. One bolt has a square head and the other has a hexagonal head. The two bolts are considered equivalent with respect to form, fit, and function: they both have sufficiently close physical shape, they take up the same space when used, and they both serve to fasten two things together. Thus, one of these two bolts could be considered to be an alternate part for the other bolt.

ext_description.p: the word or set of words describing the requirements that are covered by both the base part and the alternate part and therefore are the basis for the statement regarding the capability of replacing the base part by the alternate part.
ext_description.note: Additional properties such as performance, noise, endurance, or reliability may also be considered as a prerequisite for the replacement in addition to form, fit, function, and quality.
ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the inherited attribute relationType. The value of relationType shall be 'alternate'.
The combination of the related part and the relating part shall be unique.

A BeveledSheetRepresentation is a type of that has a significant thickness, and whose edge is beveled at a constant angle around its entire perimeter. It is an extension of the concept of a thin sheet to products, such as honeycomb core, that have significant thickness but can be formed to mate with a curved surface.
specifies the angle from the plane normal to the defining surface of part's profile to the beveled surface.
specifies the base exterior boundary and defining surface of the part.
specifies the vertical height of the part's profile from the base boundary to where the bevel begins.
ensure that the units for angle and length are correct.

A BoundaryCurveRepresentation is a set of curves that define the sheet edge. These curves define a closed area but are not necessarily restrained topologically. The curves that encompass the other curves are the outer boundary, while curves that define a closed area within the outer boundary are cutouts.

ext_description.p:
the words or set of words by which the BoundaryCurveRepresentation is known.

A CompositeAssembly is a type of that is made of multiple materials that are bonded together. A CompositeAssembly may be made from any combination of materials. A completed CompositeAssembly need not be a rigid shape. A CompositeAssembly may also be used as a composite part.
identifies constituent parts that make up a CompositeAssembly.
specifies the geometric model used to represent the shape of the CompositeAssembly. The shape shall be one of the entities. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A CompositeAssemblySequenceDefinition is a single unique sequence or layer within a . The sequence or layer contains one or more constituent parts. When more than one constituent part resides in the same sequence or layer, the constituents must not overlap. If constituents do overlap they must be put on separate sequence or layers.
specifies the collection of components in a single unique sequence or layer in a part. The componentsInSequence shall be a collection of one or more of the types.

A CompositeAssemblyTable is a type of that provides an ordered list of constituent parts. The ordered list provides basic placement position within the laminate (see following figure).
Composite assembly table
specifies the groups of constituents to be laid in sequence. There shall exist not less than two s for the CompositeAssemblyTable.

A CompositeSheetRepresentation is a type of that defines a sheet product. A sheet product is a product whose thickness is constant and small in comparison to its length and width. Most sheet products will conform to the surface on which they are placed. The shape of a sheet product can be represented in a 3-dimensional model of the actual shape, as a shape projected onto the layup surface, or as a shape projected into a 2-dimensional plane. A typical composite sheet is 0.1 to 0.4 millimeters thick while its length and width are much greater than 25 millimeters. A CompositeSheetRepresentation may be one of the following:
,
.
specifies the geometry of the CompositeSheetRepresentation.

A ContentProperty is the specification of characteristics precising the content of a or of a . At least one of the optional attributes shall be specified for each instance of this object. In the case where a ContentProperty is referred by a , the characteristics apply to all individual objects, whereas in the case where it is referred by a , the characteristics apply on an individual basis.

the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the ContentProperty.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p: the level of detail that the or the provides. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

ul.li: 'rough 3d shape': three-dimensional shape model without edge rounds and fillets;
'rounded edges': three-dimensional shape model with edge rounds and fillets.

ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the kind or kinds of geometry that an object contains. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

ul.li: '3D wireframe model': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in wireframe representation;
'2D shape': The document contains a two-dimensional shape model or contours only;
'surface model': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in surface representation;
'closed volume': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in closed body topological surface representation;
'solid model': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in advanced boundary representation;
'solid and surface model': The document contains a three-dimensional shape model in surface and advanced boundary representation;
'assembly': The document contains an assembly structure with reference to the assembled components and their transformation matrices;

'assembly with mating elements': The document contains an assembly structure including the mating components only, such as screws or rivets, with exact positioning information. This assembly representation is intended to be overlayed with the assembly structure for the main components;
'2D drawing': The document contains a technical drawing without three-dimensional shape representation;
'drawing derived from 3D data': The document contains a technical drawing that has been derived from a three-dimensional shape model;
'drawing related to 3D data': The document contains a technical drawing that visualizes a three-dimensional shape model and possibly establishes associative left to the three-dimensional shape model.

ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the language or languages which are used in the characterized objects.
ext_description.example: 'Japanese' and 'German' are examples for the fact that annotation on a drawing is provided in the language 'Japanese' or 'German' respectively.
ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p: the classifications of the Document with respect to specific criteria. Where applicable, the following class names shall be used:

ul.li: 'catalogue': The Document is the catalogue in which the associated object is listed; The Document can be the catalogue of the manufacturer.
'manual': The Document is the handbook that is supplied for the associated object;
'specification': The Document specifies the considerations that lead to the design finally chosen for the associated object.

A DocumentAssignment is a mechanism to associate a with the objects, where the assigned document provides information about the object it is associated to.

ext_description.p:
the identifier or set of identifiers for the DocumentAssignment.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
ext_description.note: This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in .

ext_description.p:
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the DocumentAssignment.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
the classifications of the DocumentAssignment.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p:
the meaning of the assignment.
Where applicable, the following values shall be used:

ul.li: 'additional information': The assigned document provides information that is relevant for the associated object, but is not a description of the associated object itself;
'behaviour': The assigned document specifies information about the behaviour of the associated object;
'description': The assigned document provides textual information for the associated object itself;
'informative': The assigned document may or may not be considered;
'mandatory': The associated object shall conform to the content of the assigned document;
'mathematical description': The assigned document specifies the associated object by providing the algorithmic specification of its behaviour.

'dimensioning standard': The assigned document specifies the dimensioning standard; The document shall be assigned to a . For a there is a textual document assigned, explaining the functionality, size, and other characteristics by a DocumentAssignment with role 'description'. Another document, representing the specification of the , in which the is used, is also assigned to the same by a DocumentAssignment with role 'additional information'.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the assigned , , , or .

ext_description.p: the objects to which the is assigned.
ext_description.example: A document assigned to may provide further description of the input or output of that activity.

ext_description.p: A DocumentDefinition is one of potentially more alternative representations of a .
ext_description.note: A may have more than one representation.
ext_description.example: A version of a logical document, which contains a shape model, may be represented in the different native formats of two three-dimensional CAD systems.
ext_description.note: The following additional data can be assigned to a DocumentDefinition: , , , , , , , , , , and .

the classifications of the DocumentDefinitionRelationship.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p:
the meaning of the relationship.
Where applicable, the following class names shall be used:

ul.li: 'addition': The application object specifies that the related document provides supplementary or collateral information with regard to the information provided by the relating document;
'copy': The application object defines a relationship where the related is a copy of the relating ;

'decomposition': The application object defines a relationship where the related is one of potentially more sub documents of the relating ; The decomposition of a document into clauses is an example for the use of this value.

'peer': The application object specifies that the related document provides required information with regard to that provided by the relating document. The peer document is essential for a complete understanding;

'sequence': The application object defines a logical sequence where the related
comes after the relating ; A sequence of clauses.
'translation': The DocumentDefinitionRelationship specifies that the related document is generated through a translation process from the relating document.

'hierarchy': The business object defines a hierarchical relationship where the related is a sub version of the relating ; 'Revision 1.1' and 'revision 1.2' are examples of sub-versions of 'version 1'.
'sequence': The business object defines a version sequence where the relating is the preceding version and the related is the following version.

'supplied document': The business object defines a relationship between two objects representing the same object in different organizational contexts. The different organizational contexts can be represented by different general organizational data associations with the related objects.

A FormatProperty is a specification of characteristics of a or of a that specify the format of the object. At least one of the optional attributes shall be specified for each instance of this object. In the case where a FormatProperty is referred by a the characteristics apply to all individual objects, whereas in the case it is referred by a the characteristics apply on an individual basis.

ext_description.p: the character code that is used in the characterized object. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

ul.li: 'binary': The document contains data in binary format;
'IEC 61286': The coded character set used to encode the document data according to IEC 61286;

'ISO 646': The coded character set used to encode the document data according to ISO 646;
The character set in ISO 646 is identical to the character set commonly known as ASCII
'ISO 6937': The coded character set used to encode the document data is according to ISO/IEC 6937;
'ISO 8859-1': The coded character set used to encode the document data according to ISO 8859-1; The character set in ISO 8859-1 is identical to the character set commonly known as LATIN-1.
'ISO 10646': The coded character set used to encode the document data according to ISO/IEC 10646.

ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the convention that was used to structure the information in the characterized object. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

ul.li: 'DXF': The document contains data in Drawing Exchange File format;
'IGES': The document contains data in Initial Graphics Exchange Specification format;
'ISO 10303-203': The document contains data in ISO 10303-203 format;
'ISO 10303-214': The document contains data in ISO 10303-214 format;
'TIFF CCITT GR4': The document contains data in TIFF CCITT GR4 format;
'VDAFS': The document contains data in VDAFS format;
'VOXEL': The document contains data in VOXEL format.

ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the dimensions of a physical presentation of the object the sizeFormat is provided for.
ext_description.example: 'ISO A0' is an example for the sizeFormat of a drawing that is stored digitally.

A Requirement is an essential characteristic, condition, or capability that shall be met or exceeded by a system or a component to satisfy a contract, standard, specification, or other formally imposed document. The term "requirement" is used here in the sense that term is used in systems engineering and similar industrial domains. There may be many versions of a Requirement through . There may also be more than one domain-specific view of a given (using the entity). The Requirement entity is simply a placeholder for holding a unique requirement. Most associations and properties could be defined at the Requirement, or level - that is in the context of a domain. A requirement may be identified as "NOx emissions requirement", and uniquely identified as "Req2". Systems engineering tools and organizations may use differing identification mechanisms. Multiple identifiers may be managed in Requirement using the id attribute.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the Requirement.
ext_description.note: This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in .

ext_description.p: the words or set of words by which the Requirement is known.
ext_description.note: This attribute supports multiple names in different contexts as well as multi linguism.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the proxies of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the versions of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A RequirementAssignment is used to relate a (via or ) to data types representing the items (specified in ) which are affected by the requirement. A requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP" could be assigned to the data types which are used to represent the vehicle's engine.

the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementAssignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in .

ext_description.p: the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementAssignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the classifications of the RequirementAssignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the or the which is assigned.
the item (specified in ) which has the requirement assigned to it.

A RequirementCollectionRelationship is a type of . It identifies a collection relationship that is used to relate a parent (collection) requirement to its member requirements. This provides a method for collecting together a set of requirements and treating them as a single requirement, whilst still being able to refer to individual requirements.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'collection': the relationType specifies that the is a collection;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A RequirementDecompositionRelationship is a type of . It identifies a decomposition relationship. This provides a method to represent a decomposition of requirements.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'decomposition': the relationType specifies that the is a decomposition;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A RequirementSatisfactionAssertion is a relationship between an item (specified in ) and a requirement (via or the ), asserting that the item satisfies the identified requirement. A data type used to represent a vehicle's engine with a power output of 160BHP could be asserted to satisfy a requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP".

the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementSatisfactionAssertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in .
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementSatisfactionAssertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementSatisfactionAssertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the date and the or the (via ) that has asserted the requirement satisfaction. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the that is satisfied by the RequirementSatisfactionAssertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the item (specified in ) that satisfies the requirement.
the requirement (via the or the ) that is satisfied.
A RequirementSequenceRelationship is a type of . It identifies a sequence relationship providing a method to link together , while introducing a particular order.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'sequence': the relationType specifies that the is a sequence;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A RequirementSourceAssociation is a relationship between a requirement (via the or the ) and the data types representing the source (specified in ) of the requirement. The source of the requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP" could be a document representing the findings of a market survey of sports car buyers.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementSourceAssociation. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
ext_description.note: This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in .

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementSourceAssociation. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementSourceAssociation. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the proxies of the RequirementSourceAssociation. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the item which is the source (specified in ) of the requirement.
the or the which is to be related to its source.

A RequirementTracingRelationship is a type of . It identifies a tracing relationship. A requirement on the performance of a catalytic converter in a car may be traced from a more general emissions requirement. A requirement may trace to many other requirements and vice versa - this is achieved by creating multiple instances of the tracing relationship entity.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'tracing': the relationType specifies that the is a tracing relationship;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A RequirementVersion identifies a particular version of a requirement. This entity is used to record different versions of a requirement. In this case, the word "version" implies "revision" - that is a particular release of a requirement. A given requirement might have versions 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 and 2.0.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementVersion.
ext_description.note: This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in .

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementVersion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementVersion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the proxies of the RequirementVersion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the views of the RequirementVersion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the that the RequirementVersion is a version of.
A RequirementVersionRelationship is a type of relationship that is used to relate previous version (related) of a requirement to the version that replaces it (relating).
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementVersionRelationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementVersionRelationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the related object and the relating object must not be the same .

A RequirementView provides a view of a requirement version relevant for one or more application domains. This view collects requirement data for specific engineering purposes. An engineer may have responsibility for collecting all requirements associated with the cooling of an engine - covering engine block, tubing, water pump, electric fan. Some requirements in a RequirementView might impact on different disciplines. Multiple RequirementView instances may be used to present different views of a given requirement for each discipline.
The definition of the requirement is represented by a set of definitional properties referenced from RequirementView.definitionalRepresentations. If more than one definitional property is provided each property shall be equivalent. Any other property that is associated with the RequirementView is assumed to be a non-defining property, such as an annotation etc. The requirement that the weight should be less than 4 Kgs can be represented by a string representation "weight must be 4Kg" and a numeric representation "4Kg" specified as a value with units.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementView. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
ext_description.note: This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in .

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementView. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementView. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

the set of objects in which this view of the is also relevant. The additionalContexts shall not contain the that is referenced as the initialContext.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the properties that define the requirement.
the in which this view of the has been designed primarily.
the proxies of the RequirementView. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the of which the RequirementView provides a characterization.

the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementViewRelationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementViewRelationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A SizeProperty is the specification of the size of a or of a object. At least one of the optional attributes shall be specified for each instance of this object. In the case where a SizeProperty is referred by a , the size information is the sum of the sizes of all individual objects that are collected by this object, whereas in the case it is referred by a , the size information is the one of the individual objects that is referenced.

the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the SizeProperty.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p: the that represents the size of a digitally stored document. The value of this attribute need not be specified. The fileSize shall only be applied in cases where the SizeProperty is referred by a or a .
ext_description.example: '15021 Bytes' and 'less than 500 Bytes' are examples for a fileSize.
ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.

the number of pages of the application object the SizeProperty is referred by. The value of this attribute need not be specified. The pageCount shall only be used in cases where the SizeProperty is referred by a or a .
ext_description.example: '42 pages' and 'more than 1 page' are examples of a pageCount.
ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.
